comments.commentBody: A wonderful display of everlasting love.

My God, you are a beautiful person. I hope for the day when your husband can remember all the wonderful things you two shared and feel blessed for the journey while feeling the loss of something so rare. It's a balancing act of emotions that only time and support can create. It gets better, but it doesn't go away.

My husband knew he only had weeks to live. He didn't Amy's words but put into action things that still reverberate today 6 years later. To show such bravery when facing mortality at such a young age, leaving behind his teenage children and a wife that worshipped him, has given me the courage to go on and be the best I could be because he was the best he could be.

Godspeed, beautiful woman. Because you loved him, he knows he can be loved. Because he loves you, he knows he can love. Giving him permission to live his life without you is a precious gift. Love to you both.
Thank you for writing this. Blessings to you and your loved ones

Tears...  that's all I can come up with.  We should all live the life you've had with such a wonderful person.  You are someone who will wring all of the joy possible out of whatever remaining time you have and I wish you and your family all happiness and eventual healing.
I believe it is the partnership that has made our marriage so good, not just one or the other!

This is the most amazing and beautiful love story I have read in a long time. Thank you, Amy, for sharing these thoughts and showing us how to confront fate with dignity and grace.  It is clear you are just as special and wonderful a person as the husband you describe. I am very sorry that this has happened to you. The world needs more people like you. Your words will live on and help many people appreciate the beauty of life.

You write: "In my most recent memoir (written entirely before my diagnosis), I invited readers to send in suggestions for matching tattoos, the idea being that author and reader would be bonded by ink."

That, to me, goes against the bond between reader and text, a bond that can strengthen, weaken, release, or otherwise change over time. The reader does not have to be on display; he or she can think, dispute, laugh and cry in private. The author, likewise, needs no permanent token of the reader's devotion; to write and publish something is to trust that readers will arrive.

I find privacy missing from this piece overall--not because you write about a personal experience (which many writers do, even those who tend toward privacy), but because you seem to try here, as before, to bond with a reader in the flesh.

Not all bonds have to be in the flesh; not all have to be known, seen, etched, or advertised.

That said, I recognize the pain and grief that you are facing.

Diana, I wish for you a bond that you would etch, advertise, make known and seen from every street corner, beach and mountaintop. I wish you both urge and reason to exult and treasure, as Amy has here in these pages.
Pauline, although your comment does not respond to my points, I appreciate the good wishes from a stranger. I recommend Marianne Moore's poem "Silence."
P.S. Moore's poem, as I understand it, has many subtleties; rather than make a "statement" about privacy, it plays with the complexity. I offer it here for its questioning.
Aa love letter to a life well-spent together. Love to you, Amy.
I am fearful of showing your  article to my wife! She may leave me for Jason. Good wishes to you both

I don't trust this particular Republican Attorney General to appoint a capable lawyer and then give him or her free rein. I agree that the need for answers is urgent, but I don't find it reassuring to have Jeff Sessions in the seat. Congress may be marginally better, as there are some Republicans there who aren't comfortable with this whole mess.

Yeah, right: I can just see him sitting down to a cup of cocoa at 11 PM, putting down his dog-eared copy of Finnegan's Wake and reflecting on the need to impose "balance" on American society.  With, of course, the obligatory degree of humility, patience and empathy.  Obviously a man whose karma has been unaffected and unimpaired by all of those leaks and paid agitators.  Why if it weren't for his sensible, level-headed tweets we'd never even know that he's alive.

You're a brace soul, putting your emotional thoughts out there on the table. Your relationship with your husband  is and does belong to you. It would be silly to think that that kind of relationship would be held with someone else. It can't, primarlirily because rather relationship was developed between you and your husband. There maybe someone out there one day, but it's not going to be what you experienced. It will be way different.

You are one of the all too rare, beautiful souls that grace the world with a unique clarity on how to 'be.' Thank you for sharing that with all of us in your beautiful last gift to Jason and your children. I just ordered several of your books to read to my little granddaughter - maybe they'll help inspire that spark in her. May your exit from the world be easy. I know your memory will a blessing for your family.

Plan "Be"... so profound. Thank you for the gentle reminder. And thank you for this beautiful tribute, not only to Jason,  it to you... as your descriptions of him and your children are reflections of you. You have given him the love of a lifetime, and in so, you have created new versions of yourself.. your beautiful DNA lives on. I pray you are saturated in pure joy and gratitude in your transition. This universe was blessed with your presence and will continue to be blessed to contain your energy and it's creations. Thank you Amy. ❤
Nice empathy try but I think you failed. Think anyone wants to hear it?

Cat London MD .  You're a primary care physician in a small city in Maine.  You are not a gynecologist or a gynecological oncologist but you responded to my comment, that urged women to get yearly pelvic ultrasound to catch ovarian cancer at stage I, by claiming that your "thesis" at Yale years ago found no benefit from screening ultrasound. No doubt your study employed technologists who require little to no certification rather than board certified radiologists performing the transvaginal portion themselves.  Nothing beats experience which your study probably dismissed in the interest of proving a point in your thesis.   I'm not sure why a thesis would be required in medical school so this was probably for a PhD. I am sure that erroneous and misguided medical advice will cause more women to write their memoirs than to live the joyful and complete life that they deserve
You brought out the best in each other - what a beautiful gift to leave your children and the world. Peace to you.

sweet Amy, I wish you consciousness in your path of transition. May your memories slowly dissolve while your inherent love grows...and grows...and grows.
Jason has his path also. A time of transition also. May you two hold hands as long as possible. But be aware, there will be a time when you and he can no longer hold hands.
Still....he will carry you in his heart...and you will carry him in your heart.
Blessings to the both of you.

Crying. So beautifu. What a treat!

Dear beautiful soul, I hope you beat the odds somehow. I wish your lovies such comfort and the futures of happiness you hope for them. Thank you for such a lovely peak into into your love with your husband. You gave me hope to find and make such a love as you did. :)

It is amazing that you could pack so much joy, humor and love into this heartbreaking essay about death. I wish for you every beautiful thing in the time you have left and I am glad that your husband will have this very public blessing and benediction to aid him in the grief of losing you. Thank you.

Wow, Amy you are such a brave, generous woman! (and a fabulous writer!) Your writing and the details you shared of your marriage are a testament to the strength an depth of your love for one another.
May you savor the time you have left on this earth with all of your friends and family. May you find a deep, abiding inner peace so you know that you are not alone in this world or the next. Sending you and Jason lots of love!
Of course we don't know each other but I wish you the very best. I'm sorry.  I hope you're healing however slow and that it will get better. You're not alone. Even if it feels like it.
I'm a widowed lawyer 51 years old, but I'd never live up to you!  Enjoy your precious days together.
